title: Team Formation - Tuckman's Model
description: Master the 5 stages of team development: Forming, Storming, Norming, Performing, and Adjourning. Learn to diagnose team stage and provide appropriate PM interventions.
objectives: Identify the 5 stages of Tuckman's team development model
Recognize behavioral indicators characteristic of each development stage
Apply appropriate PM interventions for each stage (team charter in Forming, conflict resolution in Storming, etc.)
Understand that teams can regress to earlier stages when changes occur
Distinguish team development stages from other lifecycle models

screens.headline: Five strangers. One team. Five predictable stages. Can you guide them to high performance?

dialogue.text: New teams follow Tuckman's model: Forming → Storming → Norming → Performing → Adjourning. Your job as PM is to recognize each stage and provide the right support. Push them too fast, and they'll crack. Intervene too late, and they'll stagnate.

screens.learningHook: You'll guide this team through 5 critical moments. For each, you must: (1) Identify which Tuckman stage they're in, and (2) Select the appropriate PM intervention.

screens.title: Stage Identification & Intervention Selection
screens.instructions: For each of 5 team moments, identify the Tuckman stage AND select the best PM intervention.

scenarios.title: Week 1: First Team Meeting
scenarios.description: The 5 team members have just met for the first time. Introductions are polite but awkward. Sofia mentions her 15 years of experience. Liam stays quiet, nodding nervously. Nina asks: 'What's the process for making decisions?' Maya asks: 'Who's responsible for what?' Jordan asks: 'What's the budget?' No one disagrees—everyone is cautious and polite.

quotes.text: So... how do we make decisions? Do we vote? Does Alex decide?
I'd like to know who's responsible for each deliverable.
I'm excited to work with everyone. Just tell me what you need from me.

questions.question: Which Tuckman stage is this team currently in?

options.text: Storming - The team is avoiding conflict by being overly polite
Forming - The team is new, uncertain about roles, and dependent on the PM
Norming - The team is establishing ground rules and processes
Performing - The team is politely coordinating work

feedback.correct: Perfect! This is FORMING: polite, uncertain, dependent on PM for direction. The team needs structure and clarity.
feedback.incorrect: This is Forming, not Storming. There are NO conflicts yet—everyone is 'too nice.' Storming comes later when work begins.

questions.question: What's the BEST PM intervention for Alex right now?

options.text: Step back and let the team self-organize—they need autonomy to perform
Create a team charter documenting goals, roles, decision-making processes, and ground rules
Address the underlying conflicts that the team is avoiding
Celebrate the team's progress and prepare for project closure

feedback.correct: Excellent! Creating a team charter provides the structure and clarity Forming teams need. PMBOK 6th Ed, page 320.
feedback.incorrect: Forming teams are uncertain and dependent—they NEED structure and direction. Autonomy comes later in Performing stage.

scenarios.title: Week 3: Conflict Erupts
scenarios.description: Sofia (senior chef) wants to design the menu based on her expertise: 'I've been doing this for 15 years—trust my instincts.' Nina (marketing) pushes back: 'We need customer data. We can't just guess what they want.' A heated argument breaks out. Jordan (finance) interrupts: 'Both ideas are too expensive. We need to cut costs.' Liam and Maya stay silent, uncomfortable with the conflict.
observableBehaviors: Productivity drops as team struggles to align

quotes.text: I've been doing this for 15 years. I know what works. We don't need a survey.
With respect, Sofia, we need data. What if customers don't like the bold flavors you're proposing?
Can you both stop? We're over budget on ingredients. We need to simplify.
This is uncomfortable. Can you just make a decision?

questions.question: Which Tuckman stage is this team currently in?

options.text: Forming - The team is still figuring out how to work together
Storming - Conflicts, competing priorities, and power struggles are emerging
Norming - The team is establishing norms for collaboration
Performing - The team is experiencing creative tension

feedback.correct: Exactly! This is STORMING: conflicts, competing priorities, power struggles. This is normal and necessary for growth.
feedback.incorrect: Forming has no conflicts yet. This is Storming—conflicts are emerging as work begins.

questions.question: What's the BEST PM intervention for Alex right now?

options.text: Remove the conflicting team members (Sofia and Nina) and replace them
Step in as the decision-maker and tell the team what to do
Facilitate conflict resolution: encourage confronting/problem-solving, find common ground, integrate ideas
Wait for the conflicts to resolve naturally without intervention

feedback.correct: Perfect! Storming requires facilitated conflict resolution. Help the team work through disagreements constructively. PMBOK 7th Ed, page 168.
feedback.incorrect: Removing members during Storming RESETS the team to Forming. Better to facilitate conflict resolution.

scenarios.title: Week 6: Cohesion Emerges
scenarios.description: After Alex facilitated several conflict resolution sessions, the team has found common ground. Sofia agreed to incorporate customer feedback. Nina agreed to trust Sofia's expertise on execution. Jordan worked with both to create a cost-effective plan. The team collaboratively created a decision-making framework. Maya said: 'I feel like we're finally a TEAM now.'
observableBehaviors: Team members are supporting each other's needs
A sense of unity and cohesion is emerging
Common goals and norms are solidifying

quotes.text: Okay, Nina. Let's do the taste test. I trust you on the customer side.
And I trust you on the culinary execution, Sofia. You're the expert there.
I think we've found a budget plan that works for everyone.
Finally. I feel like we're actually working TOGETHER now.

questions.question: Which Tuckman stage is this team currently in?

options.text: Storming - The team is still working through disagreements
Norming - Cohesion and unity are emerging, roles are clarified, collaboration is improving
Performing - The team is working autonomously at high efficiency
Forming - The team is establishing ground rules

feedback.correct: Excellent! This is NORMING: cohesion emerging, conflicts resolved, collaboration improving. Trust is building.
feedback.incorrect: Norming is BUILDING cohesion. Performing is DELIVERING high-quality results autonomously.

questions.question: What's the BEST PM intervention for Alex right now?

options.text: Continue facilitating conflict resolution sessions
Recognize the team's progress, reinforce positive behaviors, and gradually increase autonomy
Re-establish the team charter because the roles have changed
Stay vigilant—the team could regress to Storming if new conflicts arise

feedback.correct: Perfect! Norming teams need recognition of progress and gradual autonomy. Well done!
feedback.incorrect: The team has moved past Storming. Recognize their progress and start delegating more.

scenarios.title: Week 9: High Performance Unlocked
scenarios.description: The team is now humming. When a supplier issue arises (ingredient delay), the team solves it independently without escalating to Alex: Nina suggests an alternative based on customer preferences, Sofia adapts the recipe, Jordan approves the cost, Maya coordinates logistics—all within 2 hours. Alex observes: 'I barely need to manage them anymore. They're self-organizing.'
observableBehaviors: Team works autonomously with minimal PM oversight
Interdependence: members support each other proactively
Problems are solved collaboratively and quickly

quotes.text: Supplier can't deliver the saffron. Nina, what do customers think about turmeric as an alternative?
Based on the survey, turmeric should work. Jordan, does the cost work?
Turmeric is 40% cheaper. Approved. Maya, can you source it by Friday?
Already on it. I'll have it by Thursday.
They didn't even ask me. They just... handled it. THAT'S a high-performing team.

questions.question: Which Tuckman stage is this team currently in?

options.text: Norming - The team has established strong collaboration norms
Performing - The team is autonomous, efficient, and solving problems independently at high quality
Adjourning - The team is wrapping up and preparing to disband
Storming - The team is experiencing constructive creative tension

feedback.correct: Excellent! This is PERFORMING: autonomous, efficient, self-organizing, minimal PM oversight needed.
feedback.incorrect: This team is working autonomously at peak efficiency. That's Performing, not Norming.

questions.question: What's the BEST PM intervention for Alex right now?

options.text: Step back and let the team operate autonomously—provide support only when requested
Re-engage in daily decision-making to maintain control
Create new ground rules to prevent complacency
Rotate roles to challenge the team and prevent stagnation

feedback.correct: Perfect! Performing teams need TRUST and AUTONOMY. Step back and let them operate.
feedback.incorrect: Re-engaging in daily decision-making undermines autonomy and can cause regression. Trust the Performing team.

scenarios.title: Week 12: Project Closure & Transition
scenarios.description: The Culinary Innovation Challenge is ending. The fusion menu has launched successfully. The team is holding a final retrospective. Maya says: 'I'm sad this is ending—I loved working with you all.' Liam says: 'This was the best team I've ever been on.' Sofia gets emotional: 'I'm proud of what we built together.'
observableBehaviors: Project is complete or nearly complete
Sadness or nostalgia about the team disbanding
Transition anxiety—members moving to new projects

quotes.text: I'm going to miss this team. Can we do another project together?
I learned so much from all of you. Thank you.
I'm proud of what we created. This team was special.
Let's stay in touch. I'd love to work with you all again.
You should all be proud. You went from strangers to a high-performing team in 12 weeks.

questions.question: Which Tuckman stage is this team currently in?

options.text: Performing - The team is still working at high efficiency
Norming - The team is solidifying lessons learned
Adjourning - The team is disbanding, reflecting on accomplishments, and transitioning to new projects
Forming - The team is preparing for a new project together

feedback.correct: Perfect! This is ADJOURNING: project complete, team disbanding, reflecting on accomplishments, celebrating.
feedback.incorrect: The project is ending and the team is disbanding. This is Adjourning (also called Mourning).

questions.question: What's the BEST PM intervention for Alex right now?

options.text: Conduct a retrospective, celebrate accomplishments, acknowledge emotions, and facilitate smooth transitions
Immediately assign the team to a new project to maintain momentum
Avoid emotional discussions—focus on final deliverables only
Push the team to finish remaining tasks quickly so they can move on

feedback.correct: Excellent! Adjourning requires closure: retrospective, celebration, acknowledging emotions, facilitating transitions.
feedback.incorrect: Skipping Adjourning to 'move on quickly' denies closure and can leave team members feeling unappreciated.

content.description: Bruce Tuckman identified a predictable pattern: most teams go through 5 stages as they mature from a group of strangers to a high-performing unit.

stages.name: Forming
stages.summary: Strangers meet. Polite, uncertain, dependent on leader.

stages.name: Storming
stages.summary: Conflicts emerge. Competing ideas, power struggles, tension.

stages.name: Norming
stages.summary: Cohesion emerges. Team resolves conflicts, establishes norms.

stages.name: Adjourning
stages.summary: Project ends. Reflecting, celebrating, disbanding, transitioning.

content.keyInsight: Teams don't skip stages—they must progress through each one. Trying to force a Forming team to Perform will fail.

content.description: The team has just been assembled. Members are polite, cautious, and uncertain.
behaviors: Uncertainty about roles, goals, and processes
High dependence on the PM for direction
teamNeeds: CLARITY: Clear goals, roles, and expectations
DIRECTION: PM provides guidance and leadership
interventions: Create a TEAM CHARTER: Document goals, roles, decision-making processes
Facilitate introductions: Help members get to know each other
Set clear expectations: What does success look like?
Provide structure: Meeting cadence, communication channels
content.commonMistake: Assuming the team is ready to self-organize immediately. Forming teams NEED structure.

content.description: Once the team starts working, individual differences emerge. Conflicts arise. Productivity may DROP temporarily.
behaviors: Power struggles or challenges to authority
teamNeeds: SAFETY: Create space for disagreements without fear
INTEGRATION: Find common ground and synthesize ideas
interventions: Encourage open communication: Create safe space for disagreements
Find common ground: Help team discover shared goals
DON'T avoid Storming—it's necessary for growth
DON'T remove conflicting members unless absolutely necessary
content.commonMistake: Avoiding or suppressing conflicts. Storming is NORMAL and NECESSARY.
content.warning: Removing members during Storming RESETS the team to Forming.

content.description: After working through conflicts, the team develops cohesion. A sense of unity emerges. Collaboration improves.
behaviors: Sense of unity and cohesion emerges
Team members support each other's needs
interventions: Stay vigilant: Teams CAN regress to Storming
content.commonMistake: Assuming Norming = Performing. Norming is BUILDING cohesion; Performing is DELIVERING.
content.warning: Teams can REGRESS from Norming to Storming if disruptions occur.

content.description: The team is now functioning at peak efficiency. They work autonomously with minimal oversight.
behaviors: Interdependence: Members support each other proactively
Problems solved quickly without PM escalation
teamNeeds: TRUST: PM steps back and lets the team operate
RESOURCES: Remove obstacles, provide support when requested
interventions: Remove obstacles: Focus on clearing blockers
Provide resources: Ensure team has what they need
content.commonMistake: Re-engaging in daily decision-making. This undermines autonomy.
content.warning: Major disruptions (new members, role changes) can cause regression to Storming.

content.description: The project is complete. The team is disbanding. This stage involves celebrating and managing emotions.
behaviors: Project is complete or nearing completion
teamNeeds: CLOSURE: Time to reflect and celebrate
TRANSITION SUPPORT: Help members move to next assignments
EMOTIONAL ACKNOWLEDGMENT: Validate feelings of loss
content.commonMistake: Skipping Adjourning to 'move on quickly.' This denies closure.

insights.title: Teams can REGRESS to earlier stages
insights.explanation: Major changes (new members, role changes, org restructuring) can cause regression.
insights.example: Replacing 2 members during Storming reset the team to Forming.

insights.title: Storming is NECESSARY, not a failure
insights.explanation: Many PMs try to avoid Storming. But it's where the team learns to resolve conflicts.
insights.action: Facilitate healthy conflict resolution, don't suppress conflicts.

insights.title: Team charter should be created during FORMING
insights.explanation: Early commitment to clear goals, roles, and ground rules prevents misunderstandings.

insights.title: Distinguish Tuckman stages from other lifecycle models
insights.explanation: Team development stages ≠ Project lifecycle phases ≠ Product lifecycle stages

insights.title: Norming is NOT a conflict resolution technique
insights.explanation: Norming is a team development STAGE. Conflict resolution techniques are Confronting, Collaborating, etc.

moment1_correct.text: Excellent diagnosis. You recognized the uncertainty and provided structure. This is how you set a new team up for success.

moment2_correct.text: I facilitated a session where Sofia, Nina, and Jordan could discuss their perspectives openly. We found common ground: customer data + expert execution + cost control.

moment3_correct.text: I told the team: 'You've come a long way—great collaboration. I'm going to delegate more decision-making to you because I trust you're ready.'

moment4_correct.text: I told the team: 'You're high-performing now. I trust you to handle day-to-day decisions. I'm here if you need me, but you don't need me to manage you anymore.'

moment5_correct.text: I held a retrospective where we reflected on our journey: from strangers to high performers. We celebrated our success and I helped everyone transition to their next projects.

screens.title: Team Regression After a Major Change
screens.context: Three months later, Alex's Performing team is humming along on a NEW project. Then, Sofia (senior chef and culinary lead) leaves the company for a new opportunity. Alex replaces her with Marcus, a talented chef with a completely different working style. Within ONE WEEK, issues emerge: Marcus and Nina clash over decision-making authority, Jordan questions whether Marcus understands the budget constraints, Liam feels uncertain about his role again.

questions.question: What caused the team's regression? Swipe RIGHT for factors that caused regression, LEFT for factors that didn't.

cards.explanation: Losing a key team member disrupts established dynamics

cards.statement: Marcus has a different working style
cards.explanation: New member's different style triggers new Forming/Storming

cards.statement: Marcus is a 'stranger' to the established team
cards.explanation: New member must be integrated - triggers Forming stage
Deadlines don't typically cause team stage regression

cards.statement: The team was performing well before
cards.explanation: Past performance doesn't prevent regression after changes
Conflict over authority = Storming stage indicator

questions.question: Select the 3 interventions Alex should use to help the team return to Performing:

options.text: Re-facilitate FORMING: Re-introduce Marcus, clarify roles and decision authority
Address STORMING conflicts: Facilitate discussion between Nina and Marcus
Revisit team charter: Update working agreements with Marcus's input
Fire Marcus: Replace him with someone similar to Sofia
Wait it out: The team will figure it out on their own
Skip to Performing: Just tell them to work together

screens.title: Mastering Team Development
screens.summary: You've learned to recognize the 5 stages of Tuckman's team development model and apply appropriate PM interventions at each stage.
takeaways: Forming: Polite, uncertain, dependent → Create team charter, provide structure
Storming: Conflicts, competing ideas → Facilitate conflict resolution (don't avoid)
Norming: Cohesion emerges → Recognize progress, reinforce behaviors, increase autonomy
Performing: Autonomous, efficient → Step back, trust the team, remove obstacles
Adjourning: Project ending → Conduct retrospective, celebrate, acknowledge emotions
Teams can REGRESS to earlier stages when major changes occur
Team development stages ≠ Project lifecycle phases ≠ Product lifecycle stages
Team charter should be created during FORMING, not later

artifacts.title: Team Development Journey Map
artifacts.description: Visual timeline showing your 5 diagnoses with interventions

artifacts.title: Tuckman's Model Quick Reference
artifacts.description: Decision framework for diagnosing stages and selecting interventions

characterClosing.text: Excellent work. You recognized each stage and provided appropriate support. Most PMs either push teams too fast or avoid Storming. You did neither.
